title: Don't Call ICE 'Gestapo,' or Else..
description:
Watch The Full Philip DeFranco Show: https://www.youtube.com/defranco?sub_confirmation=1
Subscribe for more Quickie News: https://www.youtube.com/defranco?sub_confirmation=1

‚ÄúICE Chief Greg Bovino, you‚Äôre a gestapo thug.‚Äù If it was Little Greg‚Äôs decision that sentence would cause you some problems after he said this morning: ‚ÄúCalling law enforcement names like Gestapo or using the term ‚Äòkidnapping.‚Äô That is a choice that is made. There are actions and consequences that come with those choices.‚Äù

Telling Americans they CAN‚ÄôT say something is definitely a choice. Even right-wing figures joined in and called him the Gestapo. It doesn‚Äôt help that Bovino loves to wear a huge overcoat that instantly reminds everyone of Nazi uniforms. Officials said that he‚Äôs done so since 1999 and it‚Äôs part of CBP‚Äôs winter uniform. If that‚Äôs true it‚Äôs news to everyone, because Border Patrol‚Äôs own standards don‚Äôt list a greatcoat as a uniform option. 

ICE‚Äôs own actions aren‚Äôt helping them beat the Gestapo allegations. They go around asking Americans for their papers to prove their citizens, Something that‚Äôs never been required before. Running into them to do so means you could be sent to some prison abroad . All of which happens EXTREMELY fast and with little time to get legal intervention. And their identities are secret and they seem to have near immunity to repercussions. All of which makes them a de facto secret police. It‚Äôs not that complicated.

If you act like the gestapo, dress like the gestapo, and shoot citizens like the gestapo‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs fair to say you‚Äôre the gestapo. And adding that Americans aren‚Äôt allowed to criticize you like this doesn‚Äôt help.

‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

title: 100 Clergy Arrested at Anti-ICE Protest at Minneapolis Airport
description:
Watch The Full Philip DeFranco Show: https://www.youtube.com/defranco?sub_confirmation=1
Subscribe for more Quickie News: https://www.youtube.com/defranco?sub_confirmation=1

100 clergy members were just arrested for protesting ICE in Minnesota. And that is the fallout from just one of many protests happening in the state today.

The clergy members were at the Minneapolis-Saint Paul International Airport to take a stand against airlines running deportation flights. Footage showing them singing outside, praying, braving subzero temperatures to call for these flights to stop.

But they were reportedly arrested and ziptied for ignoring commands from airport and local police to clear the road. With airport officials also claiming the protest exceeded the permitted number of people.

And today, there are tons of other major marches, rallies, and boycotts happening calling for ICE to get out of Minnesota. With residents encouraged to not go to school, work, or shop, and many businesses have shuttered their doors to stand in solidarity with immigrants. And while DHS has slammed this protest and economic blackout, claiming it hurts law-abiding Americans, the protestors say they are participating to protect their neighbors and call for justice.

title: ICE Raiding Homes Without Judicial Warrants
description:
Watch The Full Philip DeFranco Show: https://www.youtube.com/defranco?sub_confirmation=1
Subscribe for more Quickie News: https://www.youtube.com/defranco?sub_confirmation=1

ICE can break into your home without a real warrant and it‚Äôs raising major constitutional alarms. Internal memos from earlier this year say they‚Äôre relying on so-called ‚Äúadministrative warrants.‚Äù These are not signed by a judge. Instead it‚Äôs literally the federal government giving itself permission to kick in your door. 

This isn‚Äôt theoretical either. On at least one recent occasion reporters say they saw ICE use this on someone. Legal experts say this is a MAJOR violation of the Fourth Amendment‚Äôs ‚Äúno unreasonable searches‚Äù clause. It also goes against YEARS of legal advice from immigration lawyers to not open your doors to law enforcement WITHOUT a judge-signed warrant.

For many others there‚Äôs a real fear that the bar for the government to break into your home is going to be drastically lowered. Homeland Security is pushing back and saying: 1. These people already had due process And 2. There‚Äôs already a final removal order for them to get removed. But here‚Äôs the problem: The Supreme Court has never actually ruled that admin warrants are valid for this.

The closest case was back in 1960, and the Court sidestepped actually making a ruling.
More recent rulings suggest they probably wouldn‚Äôt hold up, especially without an unbiased judge involved. And that matters, because a warrant is supposed to come from a neutral third party, not the same agency doing the raid. Even ICE‚Äôs own training materials used to admit admin warrants were legally questionable. But over the past year it‚Äôs reportedly told new hires to ignore that and instead follow this new memo.


All of which means we‚Äôre guaranteed to see legal fights over how admin warrants are allegedly being used right now.
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî

title: Inside ICE Detention: Stripped, Shackled, Starved
description:
We heard it over and over on the campaign trail: Donald Trump‚Äôs promise of a crackdown on criminals and undocumented immigrants at a scale and breadth this country had never seen before. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, commonly known as ICE, has swept into American cities and is detaining more people than ever before.

However, 71 percent of those held in immigrant detention by the end of September did not have criminal convictions, according to the Migration Policy Institute, a think tank focused on immigration. Many law-abiding immigrants who followed the rules in their applications for visas, green cards or asylum are being taken into ICE detention centers.

In the Opinion Video above, meet three people who came to America legally, only to find themselves in ICE detention. They followed the rules ‚Äî but it didn‚Äôt matter.

title: Teenager's First Hours in Juvenile Detention
description:
From our Archive: Viewers on our channel have watched the story of Morris and his time in juvenile detention and court. Morris was arrested on a bench warrant for failing to appear at a previous court hearing. A drug test earlier in the day also revealed he was high during his arrest. In this video, we see Juvenile Intake Officer, Liz, field a call from Morris's mom after Morris has been booked into juvie, then watch as Morris and his mother have a frank conversation now that he's landed back in detention for the second time. During the call, Liz explains the visitation process and goes over what Morris's mom needs to know before his court hearing in a few days.  

Once the intake process is complete, it's time for Morris to be escorted to the detention center cell pods, where he will join dozens of other kids who are also detained and waiting for their day in court.  It's not unusual for kids who wind up in detention to ask our camera crew and producers what they can expect once they're processed into the cell pods. This video shows the process from beginning to end -- from the pat down at intake to the kids playing cards in the cell pod to the showering-in process where everyone must wash their hair with a disinfectant to prevent lice.

Note:  Following his court hearings, Morris was court ordered to a placement facility where he lived for a period of time and received counseling and services. He eventually ran away from the facility. A few years later, he served time in adult prison for robbery and was released. 

Watch Morris's 2-part documentary here:
https://youtu.be/SswjgFqqHv8

title: 5-year-old boy taken by ICE being held with dad at Texas facility

title: U.S. citizen says ICE harassed, assaulted her during arrest
description:
A 23-year-old St. Paul woman, a U.S. citizen of Somali descent, alleges federal agents harassed and assaulted her last week.

"I got kidnapped by ICE. They came to my neighborhood, they took me, arrested me and detained me for two days. An ICE agent called me a racial slur," she said. "ICE asked to see my ID and decided it was nice to be racist and say really nasty things to me. They pushed me hard, they used a lot of violence, I got a concussion. I was screaming, I was crying, I was so scared. I‚Äôve never been arrested in my life."

Nasra Ahmed held a Wednesday afternoon news conference along with her father, Mohamed Ahmed, and state lawmaker Samakab Hussein to talk about her experience.

Hussein, who represents the Somali community of St. Paul, accused federal agents of racial profiling while standing aside Ahmed on Wednesday. He says residents are being stopped without cause, demanded to show their ID because they are "black and brown."

title: ICE Strikes LA‚Äôs Chinese Area, Multiple Nightclubs Raided, 2,000 Illegals Face Deportation
description:
On July 29, 2025, ICE agents targeted a Chinese man in Monterey Park, a core Chinese area in Los Angeles.
Surveillance footage shows a man in a light green shirt, nervously glancing around, seemingly on edge. But in fact, an ICE vehicle was parked right in front of his car, making it clear that ICE had already tracked his movements and was ready to make an arrest.
As the man loaded two buckets of water onto his trailer, an ICE agent got out of the car ahead and pretended to help him by moving a garbage can blocking the way. But this was just a ruse. Soon, four more agents appeared from different directions, surrounding him and putting handcuffs on him.
The agent who got out of the car then pulled out a device that resembled a phone to confirm the man's identity.

title: How Ice is getting away with its aggressive and secretive tactics under Trump
description:
Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) has become the highest funded federal law enforcement agency - outstripping agencies like the FBI - under Donald Trump‚Äôs new budget bill.
Subscribe ‚ñ∫ http://bit.ly/subscribegdn

The US president‚Äôs so-called ‚Äòbig, beautiful bill‚Äô authorised roughly $170bn for immigration and border-related operations - a huge sum that would make Ice bigger than many countries‚Äô militaries. Critics warn this will unleash more raids, disrupt the economy and severely restrict access to humanitarian protections.

A new detention facility dubbed ‚ÄòAlligator Alcatraz‚Äô has also been created in southern Florida while reports emerge of a succession of alleged abuses at Ice operated jails in the state since January - including detainees at one Miami immigration jail being made to kneel to eat food from Styrofoam plates ‚Äòlike dogs‚Äô, according to a report released on Monday.

But even before detained people reach jail, Ice‚Äôs increasingly aggressive and secretive actions have made them face accusations of being ‚Äòominous and clouded in mystery, and clearly weapons for the Trump regime to violate rights and literally disappear people‚Äô, according to Heidi Beirich, co-founder of the Global Project Against Hate and Extremism.

While there are efforts to curb Ice, including the introduction of a bill by Democratic senators to prohibit agents from wearing masks and 12 immigrants suing the Trump administration for arresting people at immigration courts, critics say there is reason to be concerned about the agency‚Äôs growing impunity.

‚ÄòWhen it runs out of brown and Black people to deport, Ice - perhaps under another name - will be left with the authority and capability to surveil, seize and disappear anyone the administration considers undesirable,‚Äô writes Brooklyn journalist Judith Levine.

But how can Ice get away with these measures?

Watch as the Guardian‚Äôs US live news editor Chris Michael explains how they‚Äôre about to become the most heavily funded law enforcement agency in the US ‚Äì and to read in depth about what this means for the country, tap the link ‚ñ∫ https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/ng-interactive/2025/jul/23/trump-ice-data-deportations-detention

title: ICE agent: ‚ÄòWe‚Äôre gonna come back for your whole family‚Äô
description:
The Department of Homeland Security announced Wednesday that immigration agents had launched ‚ÄúOperation Catch of the Day‚Äù in Maine, the latest state to be targeted as part of the Trump administration‚Äôs sweeping deportation push.

Footage filmed by Cristian Vaca of Biddeford, Maine shows an agent standing outside his home saying ‚Äúwe‚Äôre gonna come back for your whole family.‚Äù Vaca, 28, is a roofer who lives with his wife and young son.

Speaking to The Associated Press in Spanish through a translator, Vaca said he was sitting on his couch when he noticed agents outside his home taking photos.

"I‚Äôm here legally. I came here in September 2023,‚Äù Vaca said, citing his family‚Äôs safety and economic opportunity as reasons for the move.

title: ICE detains two minors in south Minneapolis
description:
U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers handcuffed and detained two teenagers in south Minneapolis Wednesday afternoon.

MPR News photojournalist Ben Hovland observed the arrests and said the agents appear to have rear-ended a silver-colored SUV carrying the two minors.

Agents took a teenage boy into custody after taking a picture of his face. The young man appeared frightened as he was led away to a federal law enforcement vehicle. The driver, a teenage girl, was seen handing agents a U.S. passport book. Agents appeared to check her identification before putting her in cuffs.

Hovland said the girl was crying as she leaned forward in the back of a Border Protection vehicle.

A crowd of observers gathered and filmed with their phones from the sidewalk, some chanting ‚ÄúICE out!‚Äù As agents tried to leave the scene, at least two bystanders were arrested as agents deployed tear gas and pepper spray.

Videos and photos captured by Ben Hovland and edited by Anne Guttridge

title: BREAKING: Manhunt for gunman who fired at Border Patrol agents
description:
A manhunt is underway for a man who fired gunshots at Border Patrol agents in Chicago, according to the US Department of Homeland Security.

DHS issued the following statement Saturday on X: "Today, U.S. Border Patrol was conducting immigration enforcement operations near 26th Street and Kedzie Avenue in Chicago, Illinois, when an unknown male driving a black Jeep fired shots at agents and fled the scene. An unknown number of agitators also threw a paint can and bricks at Border Patrol‚Äôs vehicles. Chicago Police Department was called for assistance and cleared the scene.  The shooter and vehicle remain at large, and this is a dynamic situation. 
 
This incident is not isolated and reflects a growing and dangerous trend of violence and obstruction. Over the past two months, we‚Äôve seen an increase in assaults and obstruction targeting federal law enforcement during operations. These confrontations highlight the dangers our agents face daily and the escalating aggression toward law enforcement. The violence must end."

title: Ice Agents Pepper-Spray Protesters Blocking Deportation Operation in Somali Community
description:
Federal agents used pepper spray to push through an angry crowd that blocked their vehicles as they checked identifications in a heavily Somali neighborhood of Minneapolis on Tuesday, amid the Trump administration's ongoing crackdown targeting the community.

City Council Member Jamal Osman, a Somali American who represents the neighborhood, witnessed the confrontation, as did an Associated Press videographer.

Minnesota's Somali community - the largest in the US - has been on edge the past couple of weeks since President Donald Trump said in a social media post Thanksgiving night that he was terminating Temporary Protected Status for them.

title: Video shows ICE immigration officer shooting dead woman driver in Minneapolis | BBC News
description:
A US immigration officer on an enforcement raid in Minneapolis has shot dead a woman in a car, provoking outrage from residents and politicians in the city. 

The federal agents deployed by the Trump administration shot and killed the woman as she drove her vehicle in the street where they were operating. 

The shooting was captured on video, taking place as the driver of a dark red SUV tried to slowly drive away from agents who were ordering her to get out of the vehicle and trying to open its door. 

In a social media statement President Trump defended the ICE officers, saying that he had watched a video clip of the incident which he called a ‚Äúhorrible thing to watch‚Äù.   He described the woman who was shot dead in her car as ‚Äúvery disorderly, obstructing and resisting‚Äù and said she ‚Äúviolently, wilfully, and viciously ran over the ICE Officer, who seems to have shot her in self defence‚Äù.

The US Department for Homeland Security described the driver as a ‚Äúdomestic terrorist‚Äù who ‚Äúweaponized her vehicle‚Äù and attempted ‚Äúto run over our law enforcement officers in an attempt to kill them‚Äù.   It stated:  ‚ÄúAn ICE officer, fearing for his life, the lives of his fellow law enforcement and the safety of the public, fired defensive shots. He used his training and saved his own life and that of his fellow officers.‚Äù

Jacob Frey, the mayor of Minneapolis held a press conference in which he told the ICE immigration officers to leave the city.  He said the Department for Homeland Security was:   ‚Äútrying to spin this as an action of self-defence. Having seen the video myself, I want to tell everybody directly, that is bullshit.‚Äù   He accused the ICE agents of terrorising citizens, saying:   ‚ÄúPeople are being hurt. Families are being ripped apart. Longterm Minneapolis residents that have contributed so greatly to our city, to our culture, to our economy are being terrorized and now, somebody is dead.‚Äù

Reeta Chakrabarti presents BBC News at Ten reporting by Nada Tawfik.

title: Hundreds detained in massive ICE raid at Hyundai plant in Georgia
description:
Hundreds of undocumented immigrants were apprehended during a sweeping immigration raid at a Georgia manufacturing facility Thursday, marking what appears to be one of the largest ICE raids at a single site in the 22-year history of the agency. 

About 450 people were apprehended as several law enforcement agencies descended on the Hyundai Metaplant site in Ellabell, about 25 miles west of Savannah, officials said, in the latest example of the Trump administration‚Äôs crackdown on immigration at workplaces across the country. #CNN #News

title: 2000 ICE AGENTS STORM MINNESOTA IN LARGE SCALE ICE RAIDS Arresting & Deporting Illegal Immigrants
description:
The Trump administration has deployed roughly 2,000 federal agents to the Minneapolis area as part of an expanded immigration enforcement operation focused on cracking down on illegal immigration and probing widespread fraud schemes. This surge ‚Äî one of the largest in recent U.S. history ‚Äî includes officers from ICE‚Äôs Enforcement and Removal Operations and Homeland Security Investigations, with the mission scheduled to run about 30 days and target both immigration violations and alleged fraud. Officials say the operation builds on a broader DHS effort in Minnesota that has ramped up arrests of immigrants with deportation orders while federal investigators pursue major fraud cases tied to misuse of taxpayer funds. Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem and senior federal leaders are directly involved, emphasizing interior enforcement after years of lax policy, even as the increased presence has sparked local tensions and protests. This deployment underscores the administration‚Äôs commitment to tightening border security and interior immigration law enforcement amid concerns over fraud, public safety, and immigrant accountability.

In 2026, ICE operations have expanded nationwide, with ICE agents increasing the number of immigration arrests, targeted ICE raids, and interior enforcement actions focused on illegal immigrants with criminal records or prior deportation orders. These ICE agents are working alongside federal teams to conduct ICE immigration raids, resulting in illegal immigrants arrested in multiple states as part of the crackdown. Officials stress that the goal is not simply ICE deportation, but also dismantling fraud networks and holding those who violate immigration law accountable. During these enforcement actions, some migrants have been reported resisting arrest, while others have complied as ICE police and federal task forces continue arresting individuals tied to immigration violations and fraud activity. The administration says the rise in ICE arrests and ICE agents arresting immigrants reflects a renewed focus on border security, national security, and the rule of law in response to the ongoing illegal immigration crisis.

title: Man dies after being shot by ICE agent in Minneapolis
description:
A man has died after being shot by an ICE agent in Minneapolis.

The Department of US Homeland Security said the 37-year-old US citizen was carrying a gun and "wanted to massacre law enforcement".

In a video showing the shooting, a number of masked federal agents can be seen surrounding a man on the floor before one of them fires several shots at him.

The incident comes two weeks after Renee Nicole Good was shot dead by an ICE agent in the city.

title: ICE RAIDS DAY 56 - Minneapolis/St Paul, MN
description:
Operation Metro Surge is the large federal immigration enforcement effort in Minnesota that began in December 2025 and continues into 2026, with agents from ICE and Border Patrol arresting thousands of people across the Twin Cities and beyond as part of what the Department of Homeland Security called the largest operation of its kind in the state. The crackdown has been deeply controversial, and there have been multiple killings tied to it. On January 7, a U.S. citizen named Ren√©e Good was fatally shot by an ICE agent during an enforcement action. On January 24, another U.S. citizen, 37-year-old ICU nurse Alex Pretti, was shot and killed by a Border Patrol agent during a protest and enforcement encounter in Minneapolis. Both deaths have sparked widespread protests, political outcry, and calls for investigations into the use of force

title: WATCH: Dozens Arrested And One Police Officer Injured in Minneapolis ICE Protests | Trump | N18G
description:
Minneapolis: Protesters Gather in Minneapolis After Woman Shot Dead by US Immigration Agent | CNBC TV18
Already shaken by the fatal shooting of a woman by an immigration officer, Minnesota's Twin Cities on Sunday braced for what many expect will be a new normal over the next few weeks as the Department of Homeland Security carries out what it called its largest enforcement operation ever.
Protesters screamed at heavily-armed federal agents and honked car horns, banged on drums and blew whistles in attempts to disrupt their operations in one Minneapolis neighborhood filled with single-family homes. There was some pushing and several people were sprayed with chemical spray just before agents forced entry of one home on Sunday.
They later took one man away in handcuffs.
A woman came out of the home who said the man in handcuffs was her husband. She said they were told that he had an "order of removal."
AP video shot by Mark Vancleave

title: ICE and Trump‚Äôs $170 billion deportation machine explained
description:
The massive Trump deportation machine is now a permanent part of American life, as millions take to the streets for the No Kings protests against the super-charged ICE crackdown in cities like Chicago.

We take a deep dive into the $170 billion system, asking how the President's expanded executive power has fueled the biggest immigration enforcement action in US history. 

Protesters in cities across America reject what they see as authoritarian moves and growing concerns that President Trump will use the Insurrection Act to carry out his plans.

The President‚Äôs "One Big Beautiful Bill" has given Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) a nearly $29 billion budget, making it the highest-funded federal law enforcement agency in US history. This massive funding push is powering mass arrests, with daily detentions hitting new highs of nearly 60,000. 

We examine the human cost of a system critics say is designed to arrest any undocumented immigrant, not just the "worst of the worst." As the No Kings rallies spread to over 2,500 locations across all 50 states, this video asks: is mass immigration enforcement now a permanent part of daily life for tens of millions of Americans?

With thanks to Dr Deirdre Conlon, Kathleen Bush-Joseph and Daniel Di Martino.

title: MINNESOTA SEATTLE LOS ANGELES PORTLAND ICE PROTESTS  Multi-Cam  01-26-2026
description:
Federal immigration agents have shot and killed a man in Minneapolis, Minnesota this morning during an enforcement operation. Officials say the man was armed and resisted, but video circulating online shows a struggle before shots were fired. This is the second fatal shooting involving ICE/Border Patrol agents in Minneapolis this month, sparking protests and calls for accountability. Stay tuned as we bring you the latest updates, video, reactions, and eyewitness reports live RIGHT NOW. üá∫üá∏
 #Minnesota #Minneapolis #ICENews #BreakingNews #LiveUpdates

Over the past weeks, federal immigration agents deployed to Minneapolis and surrounding areas as part of a surge operation have faced large-scale protests and legal challenges. The unrest was fueled in early January after an ICE agent fatally shot a local woman, Ren√©e Nicole Good, during an enforcement operation ‚Äî a controversial incident that sparked widespread outrage and ongoing demonstrations across the state.

In response to reports of aggressive tactics ‚Äî including the use of tear gas, arrests of observers, and confrontations with demonstrators ‚Äî a federal judge issued a preliminary injunction restricting ICE agents from using force, detaining peaceful protesters, or retaliating against observers unless there was lawful suspicion of criminal activity. The order aimed to protect First Amendment rights and curb perceived excessive force.

However, these restrictions were temporarily paused by a federal appeals court, which granted an administrative stay as the government appeals the ruling ‚Äî allowing ICE more leeway in tactics while the case continues.

Across Minnesota, activists and community groups have escalated resistance ‚Äî organizing statewide protest actions, including an economic blackout/general strike, urging people not to go to work, school, or shop to show solidarity with immigrant communities and oppose the federal enforcement presence. Businesses, museums, and unions have participated in these demonstrations.

Meanwhile, federal authorities are continuing operations under what they describe as lawful immigration enforcement, and high-level officials, including Vice President JD Vance, have traveled to Minneapolis to defend ICE actions and call for cooperation with local leaders to ease tensions.

Today‚Äôs developments also include arrests of civil rights activists linked to protests ‚Äî including demonstrations inside a church in St. Paul ‚Äî and continued national media attention on the debate over immigration enforcement tactics and civil liberties.

üîî Stay tuned as we continue streaming live with updates, protest footage, legal developments, community responses, and reactions from local and federal officials.

#Minneapolis  #Ice #Protests #Oakland

title: Self-deported migrants face harsh realities after leaving US for Mexico
description:
The US government is expanding a programme encouraging undocumented migrants to return voluntarily to their home countries.
Many of those affected are Mexicans returning to communities in Mexico.
Those who agree to leave are offered financial assistance to support their return.
Authorities warn that refusal could lead to detention and long-term bans on re-entry.
For one Mexican family, daily life in the US became dominated by fear of ICE raids and sudden arrest.
They chose to leave to protect their children, only to face poverty, uncertainty and separation back in Mexico.
Their story lays bare the human toll of a policy described as voluntary.

Al Jazeera‚Äôs John Holman reports from Michoacan, Mexico.

title: Homan to lead ICE response in Minneapolis after Border Patrol shakeup
description:
Border Patrol Commander Greg Bovino and some Border Patrol agents are expected to leave Minnesota imminently.

According to Bill Melugin with FOX News, multiple federal sources have confirmed Bovino and some, not all Border Patrol agents, will be leaving Minnesota imminently.

The report comes just days after 37-year-old Minneapolis resident Alex Pretti was fatally shot by a Border Patrol agent during a federal immigration operation. The incident sparked outrage in the city, leading to a weekend of rallies and protests.

In a post on X on Monday, Department of Homeland Security Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin said Bovino has not "been relieved of his duties," adding that he is a "key part of the President‚Äôs team and a great American."
The Wall Street Journal's Michelle Hackman joins LiveNOW's Andy Mac to discuss.

title: New details about 5-year-old detained by ICE
description:
New details have emerged about the 5-year-old who was detained by ICE in Columbia Heights.

Marc Prokosch, the attorney for 5-year-old Liam Ramos‚Äôs family, spoke Thursday and said they entered the country legally to seek asylum from their home country, Ecuador. Prokosch noted that Liam and his father are currently being held in an immigration detention facility for families in San Antonio, Texas.

Vice President JD Vance said that he first thought the situation was "terrible" before he "did a little more follow-up research."

"I came to find that the 5-year-old wasn't arrested, but that his dad was an illegal alien, and that when they went to arrest him, the father ran," Vance said. "What are they supposed to do? Let a 5-year-old freeze to death?"

The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) says ICE agents "did not target" the 5-year-old. They allege that the boy's father is in the country illegally, and he was targeted in the operation. DHS goes on to say that the father fled on foot when agents approached him.

title: ICE AGENTS RAID HOME DEPOT In New York Arresting Multiple Illegal Immigrants
description:
A viral video from Queens, New York shows multiple illegal immigrants arrested during a coordinated ICE raid, with several suspects seen on the ground being handcuffed by ICE agents as part of an ongoing ICE immigration operation. The footage captures ICE agents arresting immigrants during what authorities describe as lawful immigration arrests, with some individuals appearing to resist arrest as officers moved in. The video has spread rapidly online, fueling debate over ICE raids, ICE arrests, and illegal immigration in New York City.

The arrests come amid heightened tensions in New York, where anti-ICE protesters recently disrupted a Home Depot store on 23rd Street in Manhattan, protesting ICE immigration raids and federal enforcement efforts. These incidents are unfolding as ICE operations expand nationwide, with ICE agents arresting illegal immigrants in major cities as part of a broader ICE deportation and enforcement crackdown. Under President Donald Trump, federal authorities have signaled a renewed push in 2025 to combat illegal immigration, ramp up ICE arresting immigrants, and restore law-and-order immigration policies across the country.

title: Border Patrol Commander says ICE is being 'stalked' by 'extremists'
description:
Border Patrol Commander Greg Bovino and ICE Enforcement and Removal Operations leader Marcos Charles held a news conference to discuss immigration enforcement in Minneapolis.

Bovino said ICE is working hard to take criminals off the street. He spoke about working with ICE agents on Wednesday, saying throughout the shift it was a "running battle" with "extremists" while conducting "targeted" operations to arrest people in the U.S. illegally. He said officers were "stalked" by constitutional observers and protesters, calling them "violent mobs of rioters."

title: Clergy, activists protest ICE at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport
description:
Clergy members and community activists stood in extreme subzero weather Friday at Minneapolis-St. Paul International Airport, calling on airline companies to speak out against the immigration enforcement surge of federal agents in the Twin Cities.

With temperatures near 20 degrees below zero and a weather advisory in effect, demonstrators urged companies Delta Air Lines, Signature Aviation and other companies to end cooperation with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement operations.

Police detained some protesters during the action. The group Faith in Minnesota said later that 100 clergy members had been arrested.

Story, video and photos by Kerem Y√ºcel, video edited by Anne Guttridge

title: Los Angeles‚Äô fight against ICE raids | Unreported World
description:
Unreported World is from Los Angeles where families live in fear of ICE raids and President Trump‚Äôs immigration crackdown. 

Subscribe to our channel for more Unreported World episodes /unreportedworld.

Reporter Ria Chatterjee meets the ordinary people fighting deportation as federal agents target undocumented migrants across the city.
 
Los Angeles is a self-declared sanctuary city, and a supposed safe haven for migrants. But across the country U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement, or ICE, is targeting 11 million undocumented migrants, and tasked to make 3,000 arrests a day.
 
On the ground Chatterjee joins lawyer Bryan Sanchez investigating a raid in San Bernardino where unidentifiable masked men have rammed another vehicle and arresting its driver.
 
But across Los Angeles, families are living with the consequences of these arrests. Chatterjee meets families like Fatima and Fernando, whose father Felix was seized at a Home Depot where he works after 35 years living in the US.
 
The community is mobilising to frustrate the arrests. In downtown Los Angeles, activists led by teacher Ron Gochez patrol neighbourhoods, using radios and apps to track ICE movements. But the crackdown is dividing opinion, and some Latino Trump supporters say the deportations are necessary to uphold the law.
 
Filmed and Directed by: Nick Blakemore
Picture Editor: Claire Pringle
Series Producer: Andy Lee
Executive Producer: Ed Fraser
Production Company: Channel 4 News

Subscribe to our channel for more Unreported World episodes https://www.youtube.com/unreportedworld.

title: Wild moment ICE agents tackle and arrest local rapper as protests intensify in Minneapolis
description:
Rap and hip-hop artist Matt Allen, known as ‚ÄòNur-D‚Äô, has been arrested following his attendance at an anti-Immigration & Customs Enforcement protest.
 
Footage of the arrest showed the rapper flipping the bird, seemingly at law enforcement officers, before he was tackled to the ground and arrested.
 
Nur-D‚Äôs arrest followed the shooting of 37-year-old nurse Alex Pretti, the second fatal shooting by an ICE agent in Minnesota.
 
The rapper‚Äôs arrest came during an anti-ICE protest, where demonstrators and law enforcement clashed.
 
During his arrest, the artist could be heard screaming, ‚ÄúI have done nothing at all‚Äù before revealing he was a US citizen.

title: Know Your Rights If ICE Shows Up at Work! If ICE comes to your workplace, they cannot enter unless
description: Know Your Rights If ICE Shows Up at Work! If ICE comes to your workplace, they cannot enter unless your employer invites them in or they have a search warrant signed by a federal judge. If they enter without permission or a valid warrant, anything they learn cannot be used in court. Here‚Äôs what you need to remember: ‚úîÔ∏è Only comply with a warrant signed by a federal judge‚Äîan ICE officer‚Äôs warrant is NOT enough. ‚úîÔ∏è Stay silent‚Äîyou only need to ask, ‚ÄúAm I free to leave?‚Äù and state, ‚ÄúI choose to remain silent.‚Äù ‚úîÔ∏è You don‚Äôt have to show documentation or stand in a group based on immigration status. ‚úîÔ∏è Never lie about your citizenship status‚Äîthat is a serious crime. ‚úîÔ∏è Before signing anything, speak with a lawyer. ‚úîÔ∏è If your rights are violated, write everything down as soon as possible. title: Former police chief speaks after federal agents involved in Minneapolis shooting
description:
Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz has implored President Donald Trump to end the influx of Border Patrol and ICE agents in the state, saying the discussion has moved beyond politics and is now about "basic human decency." LiveNOW‚Äôs Andy Mac is speaking with former Fort Worth Police Chief and spokesperson for Genasys Evertel, Jeffrey Halstead, as residents in the Twin Cities community, as well as across the country, hold vigils to honor 37-year-old Alex Pretti. ICE continues its operations in Minnesota a day after a federal agent fatally shot Pretti in Minneapolis.

Border Patrol Commander-at-Large Greg Bovino says Pretti was assaulting Border Patrol Agents. "Many videos out there, many different accounts that you may see, that I may see, that anybody here may see," Bovino said while speaking to reporters. "That, folks, is why we have something called an investigation, to take what you're talking about, to take those videos, to take witness statements, to take officer statements. All those minute details that will paint a true picture, not a freeze-frame concept, and paint a larger picture of what really happened."

title: ICE detains 5-year-old boy, other students in Minnesota, school officials respond
description:
We are learning more today from school officials in Columbia Heights, Minnesota after they say a 5-year-old boy was used as "bait" for Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) as a means of detaining him and his father. This comes as Columbia Heights Public Schools Superintendent Zena Stenvik says four students have been detained by ICE. 5-year-old Liam Conejo Ramos was detained Tuesday afternoon. According to reports, the child was just arriving home from preschool when he and his father were apprehended in their driveway.

"This family is following U.S. legal parameters and has an active asylum case with no order of deportation. I have viewed the legal paperwork with my own eyes," Stenvik previously said. "Why detain a 5-year-old? You cannot tell me that this child is going to be classified as a violent criminal."

title: ICE detention facilities: How the nation‚Äôs massive system runs
description:
There is a new focus on the 120 facilities across the country that ICE uses to detain illegal migrants. Since the Trump administration committed to bringing about the "single largest mass deportation program in history," there has been a new surge in enforcement that's moved beyond just detaining illegal aliens with criminal records. With ICE funding from Congress running dry and detention facilities reportedly experiencing their highest population numbers in history, the Trump administration will need to make big decisions if they want to keep up their quick pace of arrests. The Post's Texas reporter Jennie Taer helps break down what it's actually like in ICE custody, where illegal aliens are being held, and who‚Äôs managing the detention facilities.

title: ICE detainee‚Äôs death ruled homicide in Texas detention center
description:
An autopsy has ruled the death of a Cuban migrant held in solitary confinement at a Texas immigration detention facility a homicide.

Geraldo Lunas Campos, 55, died after being physically restrained by guards at Camp East Montana, a tent detention facility on the grounds of Fort Bliss. The medical examiner found the cause of death was asphyxia due to neck and torso compression. ICE disputes the findings and says it is investigating.

The death is one of at least three reported at the facility in little more than a month, raising new questions about detention conditions, use of force and oversight.

Today‚Äôs incident was first reported on by the City of Minneapolis who said at the time that it was "aware of reports of another shooting involving federal law enforcement in the area of 26th Street W and Nicollet Ave."

title: JD Vance on ICE detaining 5-year-old
description:
Referring to the story about the arrest of a 5-year-old in Columbia Heights, Vice President JD Vance said that he first thought it was "terrible" before he "did a little more follow-up research." 

"I came to find that the 5-year-old wasn't arrested, but that his dad was an illegal alien, and that when they went to arrest him, the father ran," Vance said.

5-year-old Liam Conejo Ramos, was detained Tuesday afternoon. Ramos had just arrived home from preschool when he and his father were apprehended. Columbia Heights Public Schools Superintendent says Ramos' family has an active asylum case with no order of deportation.

title: Texas troopers to enforce immigration laws under new federal partnership with ICE
description:
When a Texas driver gets pulled over, the stop usually ends with a ticket or a warning. But soon, some traffic stops could also lead to immigration checks.

Nearly 60% of Texas counties have now signed on to a federal partnership that allows local law enforcement to help enforce immigration law ‚Äî a sharp increase from just a few months ago.

The nearly 3,500 troopers serving with the Texas Highway Patrol will soon have the authority to enforce federal immigration laws. It‚Äôs part of a new agreement with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), giving the Texas Department of Public Safety‚Äôs Criminal Investigations Division and Highway Patrol many of the same powers as ICE agents.

DPS declined an interview but confirmed to the News 4 I-Team that troopers across the state will be participating.

title: Krome detainees form 'SOS' at ICE detention center
description:
In a demonstration meant for an aerial view, a group of migrant detainees stood in an ‚ÄúSOS‚Äù formation on Thursday in western Miami-Dade County, near the Florida Everglades.

The detainees in the custody of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security at the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement‚Äôs Krome North Service Processing Center, also spelled out ‚ÄúLibre,‚Äù Spanish for ‚ÄúFreedom.‚Äù

The white-clad group of men participated in the carefully organized demonstration near a group of guards at about 10:20 a.m., while at a fenced basketball court in the center at 18201 SW 12 St.

There was a group of orange-clad men nearby at another fenced court who were standing together during the demonstration at the facility, also known as the Krome Detention Center, which holds migrant detainees with and without criminal records.

After President Donald Trump‚Äôs push for deportations started in January, Krome detainees reported the crowded conditions had forced some of them to sleep on the concrete floor and endure hunger and thirst.

Federal officials reported two Krome detainees died while in ICE custody this year: Genry Ruiz Guillen, 23, of Honduras, a Hillsborough County domestic violence suspect, on Jan. 23 and Maksym Chernyak, 44, of Ukraine, a Broward County battery suspect, on Feb. 20.

Trump‚Äôs pressure for an increase in detentions comes while Krome was not meeting all of the federal standards last year under former President Joe Biden‚Äôs administration, according to a report on unannounced inspections.

Last year, the federal government awarded the Virginia-based Akima Infrastructure Protection, or AIP, a $685.4 million contract to support the ‚ÄúEnforcement and Removal Operations‚Äù ICE program at Krome.

U.S. Customs and Border Protection (CBP) officers start at a solid federal pay grade, but their earnings can grow fast. Entry-level officers typically begin at GS-5 or GS-7, earning between $40,000 to $50,000 per year. title: Man is shot and killed during Minneapolis immigration crackdown
description: A federal immigration officer shot and killed a man Saturday in Minneapolis, drawing hundreds of protesters onto the frigidly cold streets in a city already shaken by another fatal shooting weeks earlier.

title: We filmed at the scene of the latest Minneapolis ICE raid | ITV news
description:
The killing of a second US citizen in Minneapolis in less than a month has sparked widespread protests and increased scrutiny of the Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency (ICE).

Alex Pretti, a 37-year-old intensive care nurse, was shot dead during an altercation with multiple ICE officers on January 24 after they confiscated a legally owned weapon from him.

The incident, which comes less than three weeks after the fatal shooting of Renee Good, also 37, has led to further protests in Minneapolis and other US cities over federal immigration tactics.

The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) said the agent acted in self-defence after Pretti, who they say had a handgun, resisted their attempts to disarm him.

However, there was no sign of a gun in his hand - only a mobile phone - when agents shot him 10 times, according to analysis of videos from the scene.

US President Donald Trump has said his administration is "reviewing everything" following the fatal shooting, but has refused to say whether the agent acted appropriately.

The facts around the killing of Good on January 7 have also been hotly contested, and over the weekend the FBI agent who initially began working with the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension to investigate the fatal ICE shooting resigned from the bureau.

It is understood Tracee Mergen resigned following pressure from the bureau in Washington DC to discontinue an inquiry into the ICE officer who shot Good to death, as videos showed her trying to drive away from a confrontation.

description:
The¬†situation in Minneapolis has escalated as US President Donald Trump's crackdown on Somali immigrants intensifies, leading to national outrage. Recent arrests by the Department of Homeland Security targeted Somalis, resulting in community panic, with many residents staying indoors out of fear. Local businesses owned by Somalis are suffering significant losses due to the increased apprehension. Community patrols have formed to monitor ICE movements, while protests against Trump's statements and actions have emerged, stressing unity among various immigrant groups.¬†Moreover, reactions within Trump's administration indicate embrace of racially charged language, raising concerns among civil rights advocates. The fate of the Somali community in Minneapolis remains uncertain.

title: Inside America's Most Dangerous Border: The Mexico Border Patrol | Full 4K Documentary
description:
Arizona's border with Mexico is America's most dangerous frontier. Every year, drug cartels and human smugglers operate with impunity, trafficking billions of dollars in narcotics and thousands of people into the United States. This documentary provides unique access to the elite police units on the front lines of this battle.

We follow the Maricopa County Sheriff's human smuggling unit (HSU) as they raid "drophouses" in Phoenix, properties where illegal immigrants are held in brutal conditions. We also go on a high-speed chase with the Nogales Police Department, seizing a massive haul of marijuana and a dangerous cache of weapons from drug runners. Finally, we witness a major FBI and SWAT operation to take down violent street gangs responsible for trafficking narcotics across the country.

This is a look at the relentless and often brutal fight to secure America's borders, where law enforcement battles a constantly evolving criminal underworld in an endless cycle of crime and enforcement.

title: WATCH  | ICE agents involved in Minneapolis shooting during 'largest immigration operation ever'
description:
(AP) A federal agent shot and killed a Minneapolis motorist when she allegedly tried to run over law enforcement officers during an immigration crackdown in the city, authorities said Wednesday.

The Immigration and Customs Enforcement officer shot the woman in her vehicle in a residential neighborhood in Minneapolis, Department of Homeland Security spokeswoman Tricia McLaughlin said in a statement.

The shooting marks a dramatic escalation of the latest in a series of immigration enforcement operations in major American cities under the Trump administration.

The Twin Cities of Minneapolis and St. Paul have been on edge since DHS announced Tuesday that it had launched the operation, with 2,000 agents and officers expected to participate in the crackdown tied in part to allegations of fraud involving Somali residents.

A large throng of protesters gathered at the scene after Wednesday‚Äôs shooting, where they vented their anger at the local and federal officers who were there, including Gregory Bovino, a senior U.S. Customs and Border Patrol official who has been the face of crackdowns in Los Angeles, Chicago and elsewhere.

Courtesy: Associated Press

READ MORE: https://www.wkyc.com/article/news/nation-world/ice-agent-shooting-minneapolis/507-3f4a500c-1400-4584-8bf0-4d7368c7b335

title: Border Patrol enforcement begins in Charlotte | Nov. 15, 2025
description:
Customs and Border Protection began its enforcement operation in the Queen City in the morning on Saturday, Nov. 15, 2025.

Charlotte is the first city where CBP said it will spearhead immigration enforcement without coordinating with ICE in the same location. Although ICE has made arrests in Charlotte, that agency wasn't coordinating with Border Patrol. 

The first reported sighting was on South Boulevard, near Baleada Bar and Grill. WCNC Charlotte spoke with a witness who had an encounter with a masked agent who said the moment was tense.

Willie Aciutno was getting breakfast when he realized that immigration officers were chasing after two people.

More from Myles Harris: https://www.wcnc.com/article/news/politics/immigration-news/border-patrol-charlotte-nc-operation-11-15-2025/275-15a691ce-0007-4212-8ef4-f6336a7664b3

title: 130+ ARRESTED: Border Patrol SWEEPS Charlotte in DHS immigration operation
description:
More than 130 people have been arrested in Charlotte in the first days of a major Department of Homeland Security immigration sweep known as ‚ÄúCharlotte‚Äôs Web.‚Äù Border Patrol agents have been spotted across the city ‚Äî outside churches, grocery stores, restaurants, parking lots, and along busy corridors like Milton Road and South Boulevard.
 
Witnesses described aggressive detentions, including people pulled from vehicles and questioned in public spaces. Videos circulating online show agents breaking a truck window during a stop and chasing individuals near businesses. A U.S. citizen told reporters he was detained twice despite showing Real ID documentation.
 
Some businesses temporarily closed after customers were detained outside their storefronts.
 
State leaders say the crackdown is dividing the community. The governor criticized what he called ‚Äúparamilitary tactics‚Äù and racial profiling, while DHS says the operation is focused on individuals with criminal or immigration histories.
 
Charlotte is the latest in a series of federal enforcement surges following operations in Chicago, Los Angeles, Portland, Washington, D.C. and other cities.
 
This video includes full coverage of the arrests, protests, eyewitness accounts, community fears, state response, and what DHS says is coming next.

title: Somalis' Mass Deportation? ICE In Action Against Ilhan 'CONSTITUENTS'; Violent Raid In Minneapolis
description:
Outrage is growing in Minneapolis after a Somali American was violently detained by masked federal agents during an immigration operation caught on camera. Mubashir, 20, says he was tackled, handcuffed, and interrogated about his immigration status despite repeatedly stating he is a US citizen. Video of the incident has sparked protests, demands for accountability, and sharp criticism from city and state leaders, who warn that federal immigration tactics are creating fear across the Somali community. Officials are now calling for a full review of recent detentions as questions mount over civil rights, profiling, and federal overreach. Watch.

title: Videos of deadly Border Patrol shooting contradict government statements
description:
Leaders of law enforcement organizations have expressed alarm over the latest deadly shooting by federal officers in Minneapolis while use-of-force experts criticized the Trump administration‚Äôs justification of the killing, saying bystander footage contradicted its narrative of what prompted it.

The federal government also faced criticism over the lack of a civil rights inquiry by the U.S. Justice Department and its efforts to block Minnesota authorities from conducting their own review of the killing of 37-year-old Alex Pretti.

While questions remained about the latest confrontation, use-of-force experts told The Associated Press that bystander video undermined federal authorities‚Äô claim that Pretti ‚Äúapproached‚Äù a group of lawmen with a firearm and that a Border Patrol officer opened fire ‚Äúdefensively.‚Äù There has been no evidence made public, they said, that supports a claim by Border Patrol senior official Greg Bovino that Pretti, who had a permit to carry a concealed handgun, intended to ‚Äúmassacre law enforcement.‚Äù

title: Guards accused of punching, stomping on immigrant detainees at ICE detention center
description:
Immigrant detainees are sharing new complaints of physical abuse and neglect by officers at Camp East Montana, one of the nation's largest ICE detention centers.

A November investigation by Scripps News discovered reports of poor conditions and mistreatment at the camp located on the grounds of the Fort Bliss Army base in El Paso, Texas.

Now dozens more detainees are speaking out in declarations collected by the American Civil Liberties Union. The records provide detailed accounts of excessive physical force by staff at the site, including claims of guards punching, stomping on and slamming detainees to the ground.

title: Drone footage: Protest at family detention center after 5-year-old detained in Minnesota sent to TX
description:
Raw drone video from the Associated Press shows immigrant families protesting behind the fences of the South Texas Family Residential Center in Dilley, Texas. AP reports signs included ‚ÄúLibertad para los ni√±os‚Äù (‚ÄúLiberty for the kids‚Äù) and families could be heard chanting ‚ÄúLibertad," according to the AP. 

AP says the protest followed the detention of 5-year-old Liam Conejo Ramos and his father, Adrian Alexander Conejo Arias, who were detained in Minnesota and sent to the Texas facility this week. There are conflicting accounts about whether the parents were given an adequate opportunity to leave the child with someone else.

Detainees and advocates have raised concerns about conditions at the facility, and that an ICE report filed in December said hundreds of children were held beyond a court-mandated limit in an ongoing lawsuit.

title: Possible ICE detention center planned in Orange County
description:
Opposition is building in the Orange County village of Chester, where U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement is reportedly planning to buy a warehouse to use as a detention center.

The Washington Post reported it's part of an ICE plan to detain up to 80,000 people in warehouses. The newspaper identified the Chester site as one of 16 smaller centers each designed to hold 1,500 people.

ICE has not confirmed to members of the news media or local leaders what its plans are for the former auto parts warehouse on Elizabeth Drive, which used to employ 100 workers.

"I run this county. Nobody's called me about this," Orange County Executive Steve Neuhaus, a Republican, said.

title: Woman dies after being shot by US immigration officer in Minneapolis | Firstpost Live

title: MUST WATCH: White House Press Briefing ‚Äì Karoline Leavitt on ICE & Minnesota Shooting Crisis | AC15
description:
The White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt held an urgent briefing from the White House today, providing critical updates on the ongoing Minnesota federal law enforcement situation following a shooting involving ICE and U.S. Border Patrol agents in Minneapolis.

The incident has sparked widespread protests and civil unrest, with local residents demanding accountability, transparency, and justice.

üîé Key Updates From the Briefing:

Federal Response: Leavitt outlined the White House‚Äôs position on ongoing federal enforcement operations, emphasizing safety, legality, and coordination with local authorities.

Minnesota Shooting Investigation: The briefing addressed the incident involving ICE agents, including preliminary facts, ongoing investigations, and public safety measures.

Public Safety Measures: Leavitt reassured citizens that federal and state agencies are working closely to ensure the safety of Minneapolis residents while enforcing federal laws.

Community Impact & Protests: The Press Secretary acknowledged community concerns and ongoing demonstrations, emphasizing the administration‚Äôs commitment to calm and lawful resolution.

Accountability & Oversight: Questions were answered regarding federal officer conduct, oversight procedures, and mechanisms for investigation and transparency.

Leavitt‚Äôs remarks come as Minneapolis braces for continued protests, demonstrations, and potential unrest, amid growing national scrutiny on ICE enforcement operations and the federal government‚Äôs role in local security matters.

üìå Why This Matters:

title: Who is Greg Bovino, the official in charge of Trump's border patrol operations
description:
(20 Jan 2026) 
RESTRICTION SUMMARY:

++CLIENTS NOTE THIS VIDEO CONTAINS PROFANITY++

ASSOCIATED PRESS
Minneapolis - 8 January 2026
1. Various of Senior Border Patrol official Greg Bovino walking near demonstrators

ASSOCIATED PRESS
San Diego - 20 January 2026
2. SOUNDBITE (English) Elliot Spagat, The Associated Press: 
"Greg Bovino has cut from a different cloth when it comes to U.S. Immigration authorities. He relishes the spotlight. He has a very active presence on social media. You see him wearing M4 assault rifles and full tactical gear, rap music playing in the background. He gets in public spats with officials who oppose the Trump administration's agenda.‚Äù

ASSOCIATED PRESS
Minneapolis - 8 January 2026
3. Various of Senior Border Patrol official Greg Bovino walking near demonstrators ++PROFANITY++

ASSOCIATED PRESS
San Diego - 20 January 2026
4. SOUNDBITE (English) Elliot Spagat, The Associated Press:
"In a very short time he's become a public face of the administration's efforts at mass deportation. We saw him first in Los Angeles, where he assumed the title of Border Patrol Commander-at-Large. From there, he went to Chicago. He went to Charlotte, North Carolina. New Orleans, most recently in Minneapolis."

ASSOCIATED PRESS
Kenner, Louisiana - 3 December 2025
5. Mid of agents, including Border Patrol commander Gregory Bovino, getting into unmarked vehicles

ASSOCIATED PRESS
San Diego - 20 January 2026
6. SOUNDBITE (English) Elliot Spagat, The Associated Press:
"He's been in just about all of the major confrontational scenes that we've witnessed, maybe not all, but a significant percentage. He has been there on camera and enjoying it."

ASSOCIATED PRESS
Montebello, California - 15 August 2025
7. A Border Patrol officer detains an individual in the car wash

ASSOCIATED PRESS
Chicago - 28 September 2025
8. Gregory Bovino, a Border Patrol agent involved in the Los Angeles immigration crackdown and not wearing a helmet, is among the agents as protesters chant nearby, UPSOUND (English) "ICE, go home‚Ä¶‚Äù

ASSOCIATED PRESS
San Diego - 20 January 2026
9. SOUNDBITE (English) Elliot Spagat, The Associated Press:
"He's in the spotlight, in your face, and he makes no bones about it that the Border Patrol, he‚Äôs taken the Border Patrol's more aggressive tactics that we see on the border and making them much more common, and almost replacing ICE's more methodical, targeted approach, he calls it turn and burn. It's a system to get in quickly, make the arrest, rack them up, and get out before the protesters arrive.‚Äù

ASSOCIATED PRESS
Charlotte, North Carolina - 17 November 2025
10. Mid of Gregory Bovino of the U.S. Customs and Border Protection
11. Wide of Gregory Bovino, UPSOUND (English) Reporter: "Sir, can you tell us what happened here today?"
Bovino: "I won't be giving a statement here just yet, thank you.‚Äù
STORYLINE:
The Associated Press explains who Greg Bovino is, the Border Patrol leader behind aggressive immigration crackdowns across the U.S., including Los Angeles, Chicago, New Orleans, Charlotte North Carolina, and Minneapolis.¬†

On Tuesday, Bovino said at a briefing in Minneapolis that current ICE operations in that city are both "targeted" and "legal."

Also on Tuesday, a jury was selected in Chicago for the trial of a man accused of putting a $10,000 bounty on Bovino's life.

Juan Espinoza Martinez faces one count of murder-for-hire. Prosecutors allege he‚Äôs a ‚Äúranking member‚Äù of the Latin Kings gang who offered a cash incentive for Bovino‚Äôs killing.

title: Family demands answers after man found dead in ICE detention center
description:
The family of Chaofeng Ge, a 32-year-old undocumented immigrant from China, is demanding answers after he was found dead in the shower room of a privately run ICE detention center in Pennsylvania.

An autopsy obtained by Scripps News ruled his death a suicide but noted he was found with his hands and feet tied behind his back ‚Äî a detail his family says raises serious questions about what happened inside the Moshannon Valley Processing Center.

The family‚Äôs attorney says the Trump administration is refusing to release key records, including photos and documents referenced in the autopsy report. A lawsuit has now been filed against ICE and DHS seeking all withheld information.

Watch the full investigation.

title: Activists Project Anti-ICE Imagery On Los Angeles Detention Center As Minnesota Remains On Boil
description:
ICE detention protest Los Angeles, projection protest immigration enforcement, activist art ICE criticism, LA federal detention demonstration

In a bold act of visual dissent, activists in Los Angeles targeted a federal immigration detention facility with a high-powered light projection during the overnight hours. The display, cast against the concrete facade of the building, featured a stylized depiction of an Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) officer aiming a firearm. The targets of the simulated gunfire were labeled with the words "humanity," "democracy," "rights," and "freedoms," signaling a sharp critique of the agency's operational impact on civil liberties.

title: Stockton vigil links immigration enforcement deaths to local gun violence grief
description:
Faith leaders and community members gathered Monday night at the Stockton Civic Center for a prayer vigil focused on justice, unity, and healing. The event linked national grief over deadly federal immigration enforcement actions in Minnesota with Stockton‚Äôs ongoing pain from gun violence, including an unsolved mass shooting that killed four people. Speakers called for prayer, courage, and civic engagement, urging attendees to stand against injustice. For families directly affected by violence, the vigil served as both a space for mourning and a call to action. Organizers say the gathering marked the beginning of continued work through the faith-based ‚ÄúStockton Stand Up‚Äù campaign, aimed at healing and unity through community action.

title: Rep. Ansari slams conditions at Eloy Detention Center | FOX 10 Phoenix
description:
A migrant woman with leukemia, Arbella "Yari" Marquez, is reportedly suffering from severe medical neglect inside the Eloy Detention Center, prompting a visit and harsh criticism from U.S. Rep. Yassamin Ansari.

The congresswoman and the ACLU of Arizona highlighted Marquez's case as part of a pattern of "horrific" conditions and neglect. Rep. Ansari noted that at least 20 people have died in ICE custody this year as the national detainee population has swelled.

"She is a cancer patient. She has leukemia. She has lost 70 pounds since being at Eloy," Rep. Ansari said. "She has described vomiting blood. She has bruises on her legs. She is very sick."

FOX 10's Ashlie Rodriguez has the story.

title: Border Patrol commander says operation in Minnesota is lawful and targeted
description:
(20 Jan 2026) 
Clients note: This item contains on-screen graphics, including AP branding.

RESTRICTION SUMMARY:

++EDIT STARTS AND ENDS ON SOUNDBITE++

ASSOCIATED PRESS
Minneapolis - 20 January 2026
1. SOUNDBITE (English) Gregory Bovino, Border Patrol Commander: 
"Our operations are lawful, they're targeted, and they're focused on individuals who pose a serious threat to this community. They are not random and they are not political. They are about removing criminals who are actively harming Minneapolis neighborhoods. For too long, residents have been told that enforcing our nation's immigration laws undermines public safety. In reality, the opposite is true. When the law is not enforced, violent offenders remain free. Criminal networks expand, and the community pays the price. Our neighbors, our citizens, our friends pay the price. Rather than confront that reality of which I've just spoken, leaders like Tim Walz or Mayor (Jacob) Frey have relied on heated rhetoric and accusations that distract from the facts." 
++EDIT ENDS ON SOUNDBITE++
STORYLINE:
Senior Border Patrol official Greg Bovino said his agency is targeting people who pose a serious threat to the community during an immigration crackdown operation in Minnesota.

"Our operations are lawful, they're targeted, and they're focused on individuals who pose a serious threat to this community," Bovino said during a press conference in Minneapolis Tuesday afternoon. 

"They are not random and they are not political," he added. 

Bovino, who has commanded the Trump administration's big-city immigration crackdown, said more than 10,000 people in the U.S. illegally have been arrested in Minnesota in the past year, including 3,000 ‚Äúof some of the most dangerous offenders" in the last six weeks during Operation Metro Surge."

title: What Is The Detention Center Process? - Jail & Prison Insider
description:
What Is The Detention Center Process? In this informative video, we will provide an overview of the detention center process, highlighting the various steps involved from the moment an individual arrives at the facility. Understanding how these centers operate is essential for grasping their role within the prison system. We will cover the initial screening process, which includes health and security checks, and how detainees are oriented to the facility's rules and procedures. 

Daily life in a detention center is structured around providing basic necessities such as food, clothing, and hygiene items. We will also discuss the importance of communication, including visitation rights and access to legal counsel, ensuring that detainees can maintain connections with their families and legal representatives. 

For those in immigration detention, we will outline the hearings and interviews that determine their status, as well as the possibility of bond hearings. Additionally, we will touch on the standards that detention centers must follow regarding health care and safety, along with the oversight mechanisms in place to monitor conditions.

title: Nightshift At The Las Vegas Detention Center, A Career As A Corrections Officer In Las Vegas
description:
Night Shift At The Las Vegas Detention Center, A Career As A Corrections Officer In Las Vegas
In this first of a new series called "While You Were Sleeping" we introduce you to the men and women who work at the Las Vegas Detention Center.  Meet the men and women of the Las Vegas Department of Public Safety who work overnight at Las Vegas Department of Public Safety's booking and detention center. We take you behind the scenes, overnight in the booking and processing area and one of the male units to see what life is like in this detention center. We tell you the training these officers go through, why they chose this career in law enforcement and how even in the sometimes chaotic scenes they keep their professionalism in tact.
